title: 107_hr613
content: The "Character Learning and Student Success Act of 2001" (CLASS Act of 2001) grants initiatives for character education. Character education in schools focuses on improving students' character by teaching ethical values and virtues, promoting a compassionate and responsible society. Character education in schools involves teaching, modeling, and practicing positive ethical character traits to increase students' self-esteem and reduce the risk of harmful behavior. Integrating character education into the curriculum fosters the development of core ethical values and virtues in students, creating a community of mature and responsible individuals. An increasing number of States and local educational agencies are promoting character education initiatives, which require access to effective methodologies, high-quality initiatives, professional development opportunities, criteria for assessment, and networking opportunities. The implementation of character education in schools requires a central source of information on the effectiveness of initiatives at Federal, State, and local levels. Grant authorization is given to the organization demonstrating the best practices in character education. The grant recipient must demonstrate expertise in providing comprehensive information on character education policies, organizations, initiatives, curricula, methods, research, and assessment. They should have a membership representing various individuals and groups involved in character education and a history of promoting quality initiatives. The grant recipient must use funds to develop initiatives addressing core ethical values, student motivation, and behavior, fostering caring school communities, allowing students to practice character lessons, and involving families. The grant recipient must use funds to develop initiatives focusing on core ethical values, student motivation, and behavior, fostering caring school communities, involving families, emphasizing leadership, service, and teamwork in character education, and evaluating the effectiveness of character education programs. The curr_chunk provides information on quality character education initiatives, professional development models, assessing effectiveness, integrating character education into educational content, and any other helpful topics for character educators. The grantee will use funds to provide a searchable database with information on character education groups, curricula, books, initiatives, and videos, a checklist for schools to assess curricula, and an index of character education websites. The grantee will provide a searchable database of character education resources, including information on groups, curricula, books, initiatives, and videos, as well as a checklist for schools. They will also offer telephone assistance and a toll-free access number. The grantee must submit an annual report detailing their progress, including the number of information requests received, who made the requests, and the types of information requested. The grantee will provide a searchable database of character education resources, including information on groups, curricula, books, initiatives, and videos. They must submit an annual report detailing progress, information requests received, and use of grant funds. Authorization of $750,000 for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. Grant to conduct character education research. Congress finds that states and local educational agencies have received federal funding for character education initiatives in schools, but there are minimal reporting requirements on their impact. The number of schools implementing these initiatives is unknown, and the needs of schools already implementing them have not been identified. Efforts should be made to determine the extent of character education initiatives in schools, their effectiveness, and the use of Federal funds for such initiatives. The Secretary is authorized to grant a 5-year grant to an organization demonstrating expertise in evaluation and research. The Secretary is looking for someone with expertise in evaluation and research, a conceptual understanding of character education approaches, experience in developing character education initiatives in schools, expertise in identifying quality initiatives, a record of research and practice in character education, a history of publishing research findings, and a partnership with an institution of higher education. The recipient of the grant shall determine schools' character education initiatives, classify approaches, investigate funding impact, and assess effectiveness. The grantee will assess the effectiveness of character education initiatives and submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing research progress, results, future needs, and grant utilization. The grant funds provided under this section will be used as detailed in the report. $700,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "eligible organization" in this Act refers to a group of organizations meeting specific requirements, including being described in section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and being exempt from taxation under section 501(a) of the same Code. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education and is required to provide information as requested. The terms "local educational agency" and "school" are defined under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
